history: Singular “they” has been used in English to describe an unspecified person since the late 1300s (it's even older than singular “you”!). Nowadays, it's the most popular choice among people who prefer gender neutral forms. It starts being {https://www.merriam-webster.com/words-at-play/singular-nonbinary-they=accepted by dictionaries} too.
Although “it” is normally used for objects, not people, some actually do like being called that way. If someone wants you to call it “it”, it's not offensive – it's actually respectful.
“One” is used in formal English when talking about a general or a hypothetical person. Recently people started using “one” also as their personal pronoun.
First created in 1890 by James Rogers based on {/he=he} and {/them=them} pronoun sets. Since then multiple versions were created, differing in declension and capitalisation.
Created by David Lindsay for a 1920 novel A Voyage to Arcturus, where it's used by an alien, third-sex species.
Created by Charles Crozat Converse in 1858, thon/thons/thonself is one of the first known examples of creating a gender neutral pronoun. “Thon” is a contraction of “that one”.
Created by Mary Orovan in 1970, derived from the Indo-European _*ko_.
Used eg. by Greg Egan in Distress (1995) and Diaspora (1998), and by Keri Hulme in The Bone People (1984).
Used eg. by Greg Egan in Distress (1995) and Diaspora (1998), and by Keri Hulme in The Bone People (1984).
Coined by Don Rickter in an issue of Unitarian Universalist in 1973.
Coined by Christine M. Elverson in 1975 for a contest to create an alternative to the singular {/they=they}. Those forms are created by dropping “th” from “they”.
Coined by John Clark in an issue of the Newsletter of the American Anthropological Association in 1972, derived from the word “person”.
Coined by Sasha Newborn in 1982, based on the word “human”.
Coined by Michael Spivak in 1990 for his manual The Joy of TeX to avoid gendering people in the examples.
Based on the German plural 3rd person pronoun sie.
Created in 2014 by Tumblr user shadaras.
